vectorData.altText: 16. What term describes the movement of the thumb in the accompanying video?
That's right!  Flexion of thumb is shown in this video. Flexion of thumb is similar to flexion of fingers!
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

In the fingers, abduction / adduction and flexion / extension occur at the MCPs, PIPs and DIP joints. Similarly, in the thumb, these movements take place at the MCP and the IP joints. 
Recall that the thumb is rotated 90° relative to the fingers. Therefore, its movements occur in a plane rotated 90° relative to those of the fingers. 
Thus, while abduction of the fingers occurs in the plane of the hand, abduction of the thumb takes it out of the plane of the hand.
In anatomical position, the thumb is extended; it is in the plane of the hand, but pulled laterally away from the hand. Flexion curls the thumb across the palm, rather than into the palm, as does flexion of the fingers
Opposition occurs at the carpometacarpal joint, primarily of the thumb. It cups the thumb into the palm of the hand, facilitating grip. The carpometacarpal joints of the fingers have a limited mobility.
